sn21.7:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn21.7:4.3: Now at that time Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son, was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.
sn21.7:5.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to the assembly hall.
sn21.7:5.2: He sat down on the indicated seat,
sn21.7:5.4: “Mendicants, who was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk?”
sn21.7:5.5: “Sir, it was Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son.”
sn21.7:6.1: Then the Buddha said to Visākha:
sn21.7:6.3: It’s good that you educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk, with words that are polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.”
sn21.7:7.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn21.7:7.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn21.7:8.1: “Though an astute person is mixed up with fools,
sn21.7:8.2: they don’t know unless he speaks.
sn21.7:8.3: But when he speaks they know,
sn21.7:9.1: He should speak and illustrate the teaching,
sn21.7:9.2: holding up the banner of the seers.
sn21.7:9.3: Words well spoken are the seers’ banner,
sn21.7:9.4: for the teaching is the banner of the seers.”
